name: Catnip
climate: Catnip thrives in temperate climates where winters are not too severe.
It can tolerate a variety of climates but grows best where summers are mild.
In colder climates, catnip may die back in winter but often regrows in spring.
Regions with Mediterranean climates provide ideal growing conditions for catnip.
sunlight: Catnip grows best in full sun, which ensures robust and aromatic leaves.
Partial shade is tolerable for catnip but may result in less vigorous growth.
Ensure it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth.
In areas with intensely hot summers, partial afternoon shade can prevent scorching.
watering: Water catnip regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy.
Drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering encourages better growth.
Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot.
In containers, ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging and root damage.
soil: Catnip prefers well-draining soil with moderate fertility for ideal growth.
A sandy loam soil amended with organic matter suits catnip perfectly.
Avoid heavy clay soils that retain too much moisture and can cause root rot.
Soil pH should be slightly acidic to neutral, ideally between 6.1 and 7.8.
extra_care_tip: Pinch back the stems throughout the growing season to encourage bushiness.
Harvest leaves regularly to promote new growth and maintain plant vigor.
